articles.title: Supreme Court Upholds Right to Refuse 'Pandering' Mail in Rowan v. Post Office Dept.
articles.description: In an 8-0 decision, the Supreme Court ruled that a mailer does not have a constitutional right to send unwanted material into someone's home. The Court held that the right of people 'to be let alone' must be balanced against the rights of others to communicate.
articles.keyQuote: A mailer's right to communicate must stop at the mailbox of an unreceptive addressee.

articles.title: Postal Reorganization Act Transforms Post Office into Independent USPS
articles.description: President Nixon signed the Postal Reorganization Act, creating the U.S. Postal Service as an independent agency. The law required USPS to eventually become self-sufficient without taxpayer subsidies, setting the stage for increased reliance on advertising mail revenue.
articles.keyQuote: Taxpayer subsidies, which accounted for 25% of the Post Office's budget in 1970, were eliminated.

articles.title: Richard Viguerie Pioneers Computerized Political Direct Mail
articles.description: Conservative activist Richard Viguerie revolutionized political fundraising through computerized direct mail, eventually mailing over 4 billion letters and building donor rolls exceeding 5 million names by 1978. His techniques would be adopted across the political spectrum.
articles.keyQuote: Viguerie's innovation fundamentally empowered the New Right's ascent by bypassing traditional dependence on wealthy establishment backers.

articles.title: Catalog Mail-Order Industry Enters Golden Era
articles.description: The 1980s became a golden era for catalog marketing as computer technology enabled sophisticated consumer targeting. Catalogs sent to US addresses ballooned from 5.8 million in 1980 to 13.4 billion by 1989—a 131% increase.
articles.keyQuote: American homes averaged 4.5 pieces of direct mail per week in 1977. By 1987, they got double that.

articles.title: Direct Mail Marketing Association Becomes Direct Marketing Association
articles.description: The trade group founded in 1917 changes its name from Direct Mail and Marketing Association to Direct Marketing Association (DMA), reflecting the industry's expansion beyond mail into telemarketing and emerging channels.
articles.keyQuote: DMA actively lobbies Congress to protect its members from legislation that would be harmful to its business prospects.

articles.title: Computer Revolution Enables Sophisticated Junk Mail Targeting
articles.description: Technological breakthroughs allowed mailers to do sophisticated analyses about who to send what mail to based on ZIP codes, census tracts, income levels, and recent purchases—much as Google and Facebook would later do with digital ads.
articles.keyQuote: Direct mailers could now target ads much more specifically, yielding higher response rates which in turn enabled more junk mail to be profitable.

articles.title: Nonprofit Sector Expansion Drives Direct Mail Boom
articles.description: The explosive growth of the nonprofit sector—quadrupling in the 1980s and doubling again in the 1990s and early 2000s—led to massive expansion in direct mail to build nationwide donor and membership lists.
articles.keyQuote: The nonprofit sector quadrupled in the 1980s and doubled again in the 1990s and early 2000s.

articles.title: Sears Ends Its Famous 'Big Book' Catalog After 97 Years
articles.description: Sears, Roebuck and Co. discontinues its legendary general merchandise catalog, marking the end of an era. The company dismantled distribution infrastructure just as the internet was emerging, missing the opportunity to become what Amazon later became.
articles.keyQuote: By the 1990s, the catalogue had been unprofitable for decades. Sears dismantled the distribution infrastructure while failing to keep updated customer lists.

articles.title: CAN-SPAM Act Sets Email Marketing Rules, But Not for Physical Mail
articles.description: Congress passes the CAN-SPAM Act regulating commercial email, requiring opt-out mechanisms and honest subject lines. Notably, no equivalent legislation is passed for physical direct mail, creating a regulatory gap that persists today.
articles.keyQuote: The CAN-SPAM Act established rules for commercial email but created no equivalent protections for physical junk mail.

articles.title: Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act Imposes Crushing Pre-Funding Mandate
articles.description: President Bush signs PAEA requiring USPS to pre-fund 75 years of retiree health benefits at $5.6 billion annually. This unprecedented mandate, combined with declining first-class mail, would lead to $118 billion in losses by 2025 and increased dependence on advertising mail revenue.
articles.keyQuote: Between 2007 and 2016, the USPS lost $62.4 billion; the inspector general estimated that $54.8 billion (87%) was due to prefunding retiree benefits.

articles.title: Direct Marketing Association Creates 'Mail Moves America' to Fight Do Not Mail Laws
articles.description: The DMA creates the front group 'Mail Moves America' to organize opposition to state do-not-mail registry legislation. The group coordinates lobbying efforts with the USPS and postal unions to defeat consumer protection bills.
articles.keyQuote: DMA created the front group Mail Moves America to organize opposition to no-junk-mail list legislation.

articles.title: USPS Begins Unprecedented String of Annual Losses
articles.description: The U.S. Postal Service posts its first significant annual loss since becoming an independent agency, beginning a streak that would continue for nearly two decades and total over $118 billion by 2025.
articles.keyQuote: USPS has lost money every fiscal year since 2007. Its net losses have totaled approximately $118 billion from fiscal years 2007 through 2025.

articles.title: Poll: 89% of Americans Support 'Do Not Mail' Registry
articles.description: A Zogby poll finds overwhelming public support for creating a national Do Not Mail registry similar to the Do Not Call list. Despite this support, no federal legislation advances due to industry opposition.
articles.keyQuote: 89% of Americans support the creation of a Do Not Mail Registry.

articles.title: 18 States Introduce 'Do Not Mail' Bills; All Fail Due to Industry Opposition
articles.description: A wave of Do Not Mail legislation sweeps through 18 state legislatures including New York, Vermont, Colorado, and Texas. Every single bill fails or is withdrawn due to coordinated opposition from the DMA, USPS, and postal unions.
articles.keyQuote: Bills calling for Do Not Mail registries have been defeated in more than 20 states due to pressure from the junk mail industry and the US Postal Service.

articles.title: ForestEthics: Junk Mail Responsible for 51.5 Million Metric Tons of CO2
articles.description: ForestEthics releases 'Climate Change Enclosed' report documenting junk mail's environmental impact: 100 million trees destroyed annually, 28 billion gallons of water consumed, and greenhouse gas emissions equivalent to 3.5 million cars.
articles.keyQuote: It takes more than 100 million trees to produce the total volume of junk mail that arrives in American mailboxes each year.

articles.title: USPS Could Lose $4-10 Billion if States Pass Do Not Mail Laws
articles.description: The Postal Service estimates it could lose between $4 billion and $10 billion in revenue if all states passed Do Not Mail registries and all consumers registered. This projection fuels USPS opposition to consumer opt-out legislation.
articles.keyQuote: USPS estimates it could lose between $4 billion and $10 billion in revenue if all states passed a DNM registry.

articles.title: Seattle City Council Passes 'Do Not Mail' Resolution
articles.description: The Seattle City Council passes a non-binding resolution supporting a Do Not Mail registry, becoming one of the first major cities to officially recognize the junk mail problem. The resolution has no enforcement power.
articles.keyQuote: Seattle becomes one of the first major cities to officially support a Do Not Mail registry.

articles.title: USPS Announces 'Every Door Direct Mail' Market Test
articles.description: The Postal Service announces a new market test beginning January 2011 to enable customers to mail saturation flats with simplified addresses to all types of delivery in a more simplified manner—the pilot that would become EDDM.
articles.keyQuote: In December 2010, the Postal Service announced a new market test to begin in January 2011.

articles.title: USPS Launches Every Door Direct Mail (EDDM) Program
articles.description: The U.S. Postal Service launches Every Door Direct Mail (EDDM), allowing businesses to send advertising mail to every residential and business address along postal carrier routes without purchasing mailing lists or knowing recipient names.
articles.keyQuote: Every Door Direct Mail is a United States Postal Service program launched in 2011 that allows businesses to send advertising mail to every residential and business address along specific postal carrier routes.

articles.title: EDDM Made Permanent Product After Successful Market Test
articles.description: The Postal Regulatory Commission approves converting EDDM-Retail to a permanent product offering after the market test proved 'very successful in making it easier for new customers to mail and increase their marketing efforts.'
articles.keyQuote: On July 10, 2012, the Postal Service filed a request with the PRC to add Every Door Direct Mail-Retail to the market-dominant product list.

articles.title: First-Class Mail Volume Drops 40% from Peak as Digital Diversion Accelerates
articles.description: First-Class Mail volume continues its steep decline, down 40% from 2006 peak levels. The main driver is 'electronic diversion'—the replacement of physical mail with email, texting, social media, and online bill payment.
articles.keyQuote: The main driver of declining mail volumes has been 'electronic diversion'—the replacement of physical mail with electronic alternatives.

articles.title: Sierra Club: 'Let's Ban Junk Mail Already'
articles.description: The Sierra Club publishes a major feature calling for junk mail reform, citing statistics from San Jose State University that 80-100 million trees are cut annually for junk mail and 41 pounds per adult ends up in mailboxes each year.
articles.keyQuote: An American adult receives 41 pounds of junk mail a year. To produce this much paper requires cutting down somewhere between 80 million and 100 million trees annually.

articles.title: NASA Study: Pulpwood Production Causes Highest Forest Carbon Release
articles.description: A NASA-funded study finds that the production of pulpwood—used for paper products including junk mail—leads to the highest forest carbon release out of all wood products.
articles.keyQuote: The production of pulpwood leads to the highest forest carbon release out of all wood products.

articles.title: Direct Marketing Association Acquired by Association of National Advertisers
articles.description: The Association of National Advertisers (ANA) acquires the Data & Marketing Association (formerly Direct Marketing Association), creating the largest marketing trade association in the United States.
articles.keyQuote: ANA bought the Data & Marketing Association, making it the biggest trade association in the U.S. for marketing.

articles.title: 'Do Not Deliver' EDDM Petition Launched on Change.org
articles.description: The 'Do Not Deliver: U.S. Postal Service EDDM junk mail' petition launches on Change.org, calling for USPS to create an opt-out mechanism for Every Door Direct Mail. The petition gains thousands of signatures from frustrated consumers.
articles.keyQuote: Consumers cannot unsubscribe from advertising delivered by their own government.

articles.title: COVID-19 Pandemic Causes 15% Drop in Marketing Mail Volume
articles.description: Marketing Mail (junk mail) volume plunges 15.2% during the COVID-19 pandemic as businesses cut advertising spending to preserve cash. First-Class Mail drops 4.2% while package volume surges 18.8% due to e-commerce boom.
articles.keyQuote: Marketing Mail declined 11.5 billion pieces, or 15.2 percent. The coronavirus recession suppressed Marketing Mail by an estimated 30-50 percent in April and May.

articles.title: USPS Delivers 1.6 Billion Political Mail Pieces Before 2020 Election
articles.description: From September 1 through November 3, 2020, the Postal Service processed over 1.6 billion Political Mail pieces included in service performance measurement, in addition to 134 million Election Mail pieces.
articles.keyQuote: The Postal Service processed almost 134 million Election Mail pieces and over 1.6 billion Political Mail pieces.

articles.title: Postal Service Reform Act Repeals Pre-Funding Mandate After 16 Years
articles.description: President Biden signs the Postal Service Reform Act (PSRA), repealing the 2006 pre-funding mandate that had contributed to $118 billion in USPS losses. The law also codifies 6-day-a-week mail delivery.
articles.keyQuote: PSRA is the first major legislative change to USPS since Congress passed the Postal Accountability Enhancement Act (PAEA) in 2006.

articles.title: Direct Mail Volume Plunges 13.4%—Largest Drop Since 2009 Recession
articles.description: Direct mail volume drops 13.4% to under 63 billion pieces, marking the largest pullback since the 2009 recession. Volume is now 23% smaller than 2019 levels as digital marketing continues to capture advertising budgets.
articles.keyQuote: Direct mail volumes dropped by 13.4% last year to under 63 billion, with the year-over-year decline marking 'the largest pullback since the 2009 recession.'

articles.title: FBI: Elder Fraud Losses Reach $3.4 Billion in 2023
articles.description: The FBI reports that scams targeting individuals aged 60 and older caused over $3.4 billion in losses in 2023, an 11% increase from the prior year. Many scams originate through physical mail targeting seniors.
articles.keyQuote: Scams targeting individuals aged 60 and older caused over $3.4 billion in losses in 2023—an increase of approximately 11% from the year prior.

articles.title: EDDM Program Reaches 33 Billion Pieces Sent Since 2011
articles.description: Since its 2011 launch, more than 33 billion pieces of Every Door Direct Mail have been sent, resulting in $5 billion in revenue for USPS. The program continues to have no opt-out mechanism for consumers.
articles.keyQuote: Since 2011, more than 33 billion pieces of Every Door Direct Mail pieces have been sent, resulting in $5 billion in revenue.

articles.title: Nearly 3 Billion EDDM Pieces Sent in 2024, Generating $588 Million
articles.description: USPS reports nearly 3 billion EDDM pieces were sent in 2024, totaling $588 million in revenue. Consumers have no way to opt out of receiving this mail despite repeated requests for a registry.
articles.keyQuote: Nearly 3 billion pieces were sent in 2024, totaling $588 million in revenue.

articles.title: 3.37 Billion Political Mail Pieces Delivered in 2024 Election Cycle
articles.description: USPS delivered 3.37 billion pieces of Political and Election Mail in the 2024 election cycle, flooding mailboxes with campaign advertising that recipients cannot opt out of receiving.
articles.keyQuote: 3.37 billion pieces of Political and Election Mail were delivered in 2024.

articles.title: FBI: Elder Fraud Losses Surge to $4.9 Billion in 2024
articles.description: According to FBI data, seniors lost $4.885 billion to scammers in 2024—a 46% increase in complaints and 43% increase in losses from 2023. Mail-based fraud remains a significant vector for targeting elderly victims.
articles.keyQuote: In 2024 there was a total of $4.885 billion in losses from 147,127 complaints. This is a 46% increase in complaints from 2023.

articles.title: USPS Cumulative Losses Reach $118 Billion Since 2007
articles.description: The U.S. Postal Service's net losses have totaled approximately $118 billion from fiscal years 2007 through 2025, despite growing reliance on advertising mail revenue and the EDDM program.
articles.keyQuote: USPS has lost money every fiscal year since 2007. Its net losses have totaled approximately $118 billion from fiscal years 2007 through 2025.

articles.title: U.S. Direct Mail Advertising Market Projected at $20.86 Billion for 2025
articles.description: Despite declining volumes, the U.S. direct mail advertising market is projected to reach $20.86 billion in 2025, with slow growth expected through 2030. The industry continues despite overwhelming consumer preference for opt-out options.
articles.keyQuote: The United States will generate the highest ad spending in direct mail, with $20.86 billion in 2025.

articles.title: 100 Million Trees Cut Annually for Junk Mail Production
articles.source: Center for Development of Recycling / Sierra Club
articles.description: Research from San Jose State University's Center for Development of Recycling confirms that 80-100 million trees are cut annually to produce the volume of junk mail sent to American households.
articles.keyQuote: To produce this much paper requires cutting down somewhere between 80 million and 100 million trees annually.

articles.title: Junk Mail Deforestation Equals Clearcutting Rocky Mountain National Park Every 4 Months
articles.description: ForestEthics calculates that the 100 million trees destroyed annually for junk mail equals clearcutting the entire Rocky Mountain National Park every four months.
articles.keyQuote: That's the equivalent of clearcutting the entire Rocky Mountain National Park every 4 months.

articles.title: Junk Mail Production Consumes 28 Billion Gallons of Water Annually
articles.description: ForestEthics research shows that junk mail production in the U.S. consumes more than 28 billion gallons of water annually, contributing to water stress in paper-producing regions.
articles.keyQuote: Junk mail production in the U.S. consumes more than 96.7 billion gallons of water.

articles.title: Junk Mail Emissions Equal 3.5 Million Cars on the Road
articles.description: The ForestEthics 'Climate Change Enclosed' report calculates that annual greenhouse gas emissions from junk mail production are equal to those of 3.5 million cars.
articles.keyQuote: The annual greenhouse-gas emissions from the production of junk mail are equal to those of 3.5 million cars.

articles.title: EPA: 44% of Junk Mail Thrown Away Unopened
articles.description: According to EPA estimates, 44% of junk mail is thrown away unopened, going directly from mailbox to landfill without ever being read by the intended recipient.
articles.keyQuote: An estimated 44 percent of junk mail is thrown away unopened.

articles.title: Junk Mail Accounts for 5 Million Tons of Paper Waste Annually
articles.description: According to the EPA, junk mail accounts for more than 5 million tons of paper waste annually, much of which ends up in landfills where it decomposes and releases methane.
articles.keyQuote: Junk mail accounts for more than 5 million tons of paper waste annually.

articles.title: 60% of Junk Mail Ends Up in Landfills
articles.description: EPA data shows that 60% of junk mail ends up in landfills rather than being recycled. Sitting in landfill heaps, these waste papers decompose and release methane, a greenhouse gas 23 times more potent than CO2.
articles.keyQuote: 60% of this mail ends up in landfills. Sitting in landfill heaps, these waste papers start decomposing and spewing enormous quantities of methane.

articles.title: Average American Adult Receives 41 Pounds of Junk Mail Annually
articles.source: Center for Development of Recycling, San Jose State University
articles.description: Research from San Jose State University shows that an average American adult receives 41 pounds of junk mail per year, requiring significant time to sort and dispose of unwanted advertisements.
articles.keyQuote: An American adult receives 41 pounds of junk mail a year.

articles.title: FTC: Consumers Bear 'Inordinate' Burden to Stop Unwanted Mail
articles.description: Despite numerous opt-out options, recipients continue to bear the burden of spending inordinate time and energy opting out of something they never solicited. No single government agency oversees the various forms of unwanted communication.
articles.keyQuote: Recipients continue to bear the burden of spending an inordinate amount of time and energy on opting out of something that they did not solicit in the first place.

articles.title: $60 Billion Spent on Direct Mail Advertising Annually
articles.description: At its peak, estimates suggest $60 billion—or 21% of all advertising dollars in the United States—was spent on advertising mail, making it a significant portion of the overall advertising economy.
articles.keyQuote: Estimates suggest $60 billion—or 21% of all advertising dollars in the United States—is spent on advertising mail.

articles.title: 'Junk Mail' Term Popularized by Newspaper Publishers in 1954
articles.description: The phrase 'junk mail' first appeared occasionally in 1910, but newspaper publishers popularized it after 1953 to describe direct mail advertising that competed with their classified ad revenue.
articles.keyQuote: After August 1953, 'junk mail' was used by newspaper publishers more and more to describe direct mail. By 1954 they had popularized the phrase.

articles.title: Direct Mail Advertising Industry Worth $11.3 Billion in 2025
articles.description: Industry revenue has declined at a CAGR of 0.3% over the past five years, reaching an estimated $11.3 billion in 2025. Digital marketing increasingly siphons demand from direct mail advertisers.
articles.keyQuote: Industry revenue has declined at a CAGR of 0.3% over the past five years, to reach an estimated $11.3 billion in 2025.

articles.title: No Legal Opt-Out Requirement for Physical Junk Mail Unlike Email
articles.description: While CAN-SPAM requires opt-out mechanisms for commercial email, state and federal law provides no equivalent protections for physical direct mail. Opt-out mechanisms for postal mail are not required by law.
articles.keyQuote: Opt-out mechanisms for direct postal mail are not required by law and are rarely if ever present.

articles.title: 18 USC 1725: Federal Law Grants USPS Exclusive Mailbox Access
articles.description: Federal law (18 USC 1725) grants the U.S. Postal Service exclusive access to residential mailboxes. Only USPS can deposit items in your mailbox, meaning consumers cannot simply refuse delivery of unwanted advertising mail.
articles.keyQuote: Only the U.S. Postal Service can legally place items in residential mailboxes.

articles.title: Marketing Mail Volume Down 40% Since 2008
articles.description: Marketing Mail volume has decreased 40 percent overall, from 99 billion pieces to 59 billion pieces between FYs 2008 and 2023, primarily due to electronic diversion to digital advertising channels.
articles.keyQuote: Marketing Mail volume decreased 40 percent overall, from 99 billion pieces to 59 billion pieces between FYs 2008 and 2023.

articles.title: USPS Annual Revenue Reaches $79.5 Billion in FY2024
articles.description: Despite declining mail volumes, USPS generated $79.5 billion in operating revenue in fiscal year 2024, with advertising mail remaining a significant revenue source despite consumer opposition.
articles.keyQuote: USPS generated operating revenue of approximately $79.5 billion in fiscal year 2024.
